conclusion: Analyze the Stirling cycle and molecular speed distribution between states D and A.
The P-V diagram shows a Stirling cycle with four processes: A→B, B→C, C→D, D→A.
A→B: Isothermal expansion (pressure decreases, volume increases, temperature constant).
B→C: Isochoric cooling (pressure decreases, volume constant, temperature decreases).
C→D: Isothermal compression (pressure increases, volume decreases, temperature constant).
D→A: Isochoric heating (pressure increases, volume constant, temperature increases).
The second image highlights the process D→A with a red line.
During the D→A process, volume remains constant.
During the D→A process, pressure increases.
During the D→A process, temperature increases (since P ∝ T at constant V according to the ideal gas law PV = nRT).
The speed distribution of gas molecules is described by the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution.
Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution depends primarily on temperature.
When temperature increases, the peak of the distribution shifts to higher speeds.
When temperature increases, the distribution becomes wider/more spread out.
When temperature increases, the height of the peak decreases to maintain the same area under the curve.
At higher temperatures, molecules have more kinetic energy and thus higher average speeds.
The speed distribution curve of the gas molecules changes during the D→A process.
Since this is an isochoric heating process where temperature increases, the Maxwell-Boltzmann speed distribution shifts toward higher speeds, becomes broader, and its peak height decreases.
The molecules have higher average kinetic energy at state A than at state D.
